articles.title: N. Papathanasis: “The planning for the new programming period of Interreg 2028 – 2034 has started”
articles.summary: "Greece manages five Interreg programs with Bulgaria, Italy, North Macedonia, Cyprus, and Albania and participates in eight interregional cooperation programs. We have over 2,500 actions that have been implemented in Greece with common benefits for neighboring countries and significant contributions to local communities and economies," emphasized the Deputy Minister of National Economy and Finance, Nikos Papathanasis.
articles.content:
“Greece manages five Interreg programs with Bulgaria, Italy, North Macedonia, Cyprus, and Albania and participates in eight interregional cooperation programs. We have over 2,500 actions that have been implemented in Greece with common benefits for neighboring countries and significant contributions to local communities and economies,” emphasized the Deputy Minister of National Economy and Finance, Nikos Papathanasis.

The planning for the new programming period of the Interreg program 2028 – 2034 has begun, and the European Commission proposes the allocation of resources amounting to 10 billion euros for Interreg programs, as emphasized this evening by the Deputy Minister of National Economy and Finance, Nikos Papathanasis, greeting an event for the 35 years of the Interreg program and its 20 years in Thessaloniki, focusing on the power of cooperation for European and Regional Cohesion. He highlighted that “Greece can and must take an even more leading role and act as a gateway for cooperation between the EU, the Balkans, and the Mediterranean.”

“Europe has stood with great solidarity in all the major problems that have arisen for all member states and for the countries of the region, and the Europe of peoples continues this path,” he said, adding: “A stable pillar is the European perspective of peace and solidarity among peoples.”

In more detail, the Deputy Minister of National Economy and Finance characterized Interreg as a very important program for our region and a mechanism for building trust and stability, adding that Greece is at the forefront of this European territorial cooperation by participating in all Interreg programs concerning Southeast Europe, the Mediterranean, and the Adriatic and Ionian region. “Greece manages five Interreg programs with Bulgaria, Italy, North Macedonia, Cyprus, and Albania and participates in eight interregional cooperation programs. We have over 2,500 actions that have been implemented in Greece with common benefits for neighboring countries and significant contributions to local communities and economies. Today, within the framework of the 5 programs, over 70% of the resources have been activated with 105 projects budgeted at 240 million euros,” he emphasized. A characteristic example, as he said, is the cross-border crossing of Prespa, Laimos, Markova Noga of the Greece – North Macedonia program.

Interreg won three out of the six regional awards

On her part, European Commission official Maria Galefska stated that the European Commission has collaborated with national, regional, and local authorities in Greece, characterized Greece as a leader in the European strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region, and stated that she is present at today’s event to confirm the cooperation of Greek entities.

Additionally, she mentioned that the European Commission awards the RegioStars Awards every year, which are also called the Oscars for this specific sector, the final for 2025 took place last week in Brussels, and there were 25 finalists selected by an independent committee. Ten projects came from Interreg, and in the end, out of the 6 awards that were given, Interreg won 3. “In Interreg, we had only 3% of the total cohesion policy budget, and we managed to win 50% of the awards,” she noted.

She also spoke about two Greek Interreg programs: one was a finalist in the 2025 awards and was the rewater project, which came from Interreg Greece – Italy for the protection of natural resources, and the other was the BalkanRoad from the Interreg Balkan Med program, and projects from it were finalists in the awards. “The Greek projects add value to excellence as they promote the European values they focus on: democracy, cooperation, and equality, which are fundamental characteristics of Interreg,” added Ms. Galefska.

On her part, the General Secretary of the Regional Development Partnership Agreement (ESPA), Vasiliki Pantelopoulou emphasized that Greece is currently participating in 13 Interreg programs, of which 5 are under Greek management. Hundreds of projects have been implemented through these. Only during the period 2014 – 2020, more than 3,000 institutions, municipalities, entities, and businesses collaborated, investing over 600 million euros in joint actions. In the current period 2021-2027, the budget for the programs is over 300 million euros, while 80% of the available resources have been activated for projects that serve the major European priorities, which are the green and digital transition, resilience to crises, and strengthening social cohesion.

Greeting the event, the Deputy Minister of Interior (Macedonia – Thrace sector) Kostas Gioulekas emphasized that what separated us in the past is an opportunity to become the bridge that will unite us in the future, and Interreg, because Greece is one of its oldest members, gives us the financial capability to build bridges between states. He also assured that the Greek government, under the mandate of the Prime Minister himself, will continue to support these programs of European convergence and cohesion that have been successfully implemented for 35 years.

The Mayor of Thessaloniki, Stelios Angeloudis, during his greeting at the event, said that Thessaloniki, due to its position and activities, rightfully hosts the headquarters of the program management service, referring to a highly productive, fast, and particularly effective service, while commenting that the Municipality of Thessaloniki is now opening European funding tools with particular speed, while two European territorial cooperation groups are underway that allow issues to progress more quickly.

Discussion on the impact of Interreg programs on Regional Development

During the discussion on the impact of Interreg programs on Regional Development and Cohesion Policy, the Regional Governor of Western Macedonia, Giorgos Amanatidis, emphasized that the Region is in a phase of economic and social transition and characterized Interreg as an important tool for extroversion in areas such as tourism, entrepreneurship, and social exchanges. “What started with Interreg can find use in the post-lignite period,” he said, while also referring to the border station at Laimos of Prespa, saying: “We already have a contractor, and work will begin, approximately 6.5 million euros. At the same time, the Ministry of Interior is coming with another 6.5 million euros and is funding the road connection, and we are gradually creating, with the Prespa Protection Company and environmental organizations, a unified space in the Prespa area where those coming to Ohrid will have significant reasons to come to the Prespa area and vice versa.”

Furthermore, the Regional Governor of Crete, Stavros Arnaoutakis, referred to his experience 35 years ago and the cooperation that needed to start among local communities, while the Regional Governor of Epirus, Alexandros Kahrimanis, spoke about projects such as the thermal baths in the Konitsa area, the restoration of frescoes, the Mastorochoria, composting in Arta, fish farming in Igoumenitsa, etc. The Regional Governor of North Aegean, Kostas Moutzouris, emphasized the need to realign the programs, and the Regional Governor of Eastern Macedonia and Thrace, Christodoulos Topshidis, pointed out that the region is the border of Greece and Europe, which is why cross-border cooperation plays a very significant role, and Interreg acts as a lever for development. (20/10/25)

articles.reasoning: The article reports on the significant and ongoing positive impact of the Interreg programs managed by Greece, which foster cross-border cooperation, regional development, social cohesion, and environmental protection across multiple countries. The programs have broad scope, measurable benefits for local communities and economies, and substantial EU funding, with clear examples of successful projects and future plans, fulfilling criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: Greece leads new phase of Interreg programs boosting regional cooperation and development
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Greece works with neighboring countries through Interreg programs, which are projects supported by the European Union to help regions cooperate and develop together. These programs aim to improve local economies, protect the environment, and strengthen ties between countries.

**What happened** – Planning has started for the next Interreg period from 2028 to 2034, with the European Commission proposing a budget of 10 billion euros. Greece currently manages five Interreg programs with Bulgaria, Italy, North Macedonia, Cyprus, and Albania and participates in eight others. So far, over 2,500 actions have been carried out, benefiting local communities and neighboring countries. Greece has also won important awards for its projects, including environmental protection and infrastructure improvements.

**Impact** – The Interreg programs help build trust and peace between countries by supporting projects that improve daily life, like border crossings, tourism, and environmental care. Greece plays a key role as a connection point between the European Union, the Balkans, and the Mediterranean. These programs also support important goals like green energy, digital technology, and social unity. For example, the Prespa border crossing project will improve travel and cooperation between Greece and North Macedonia.

**What's next step** – The new program period will focus on continuing successful projects and starting new ones that address current challenges, such as climate change and economic recovery. Greece aims to take an even stronger leadership role in these efforts. Local governments and organizations will keep working together to make the most of the available funds and opportunities.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Greece is preparing to lead the next phase of EU-supported Interreg programs, continuing to strengthen regional cooperation and improve communities across borders.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Grèce prépare une nouvelle phase des programmes Interreg pour renforcer la coopération régionale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Grèce collabore avec ses pays voisins grâce aux programmes Interreg, des projets soutenus par l’Union européenne pour aider les régions à coopérer et se développer ensemble. Ces programmes visent à améliorer les économies locales, protéger l’environnement et renforcer les liens entre pays.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La planification de la prochaine période Interreg 2028-2034 a commencé, avec une proposition de budget de 10 milliards d’euros par la Commission européenne. La Grèce gère actuellement cinq programmes Interreg avec la Bulgarie, l’Italie, la Macédoine du Nord, Chypre et l’Albanie, et participe à huit autres. Plus de 2 500 actions ont été réalisées, profitant aux communautés locales et aux pays voisins. La Grèce a aussi remporté des prix importants pour ses projets, notamment dans la protection de l’environnement et les infrastructures.

**Impact** – Les programmes Interreg aident à bâtir la confiance et la paix entre pays en soutenant des projets qui améliorent la vie quotidienne, comme les passages frontaliers, le tourisme ou la protection de la nature. La Grèce joue un rôle clé comme point de connexion entre l’Union européenne, les Balkans et la Méditerranée. Ces programmes soutiennent aussi des objectifs importants comme l’énergie verte, la technologie numérique et l’unité sociale. Par exemple, le projet de passage frontalier de Prespa améliorera les échanges entre la Grèce et la Macédoine du Nord.

**Prochaines étapes** – La nouvelle période de programmes continuera les projets réussis et en lancera de nouveaux pour répondre aux défis actuels, comme le changement climatique et la relance économique. La Grèce veut renforcer son rôle de leader dans ces efforts. Les gouvernements locaux et les organisations continueront à collaborer pour tirer le meilleur parti des fonds et des opportunités.

**Message clé en une phrase** – La Grèce se prépare à diriger la prochaine phase des programmes Interreg soutenus par l’UE, renforçant la coopération régionale et l’amélioration des communautés transfrontalières.
articles.personality_title_es: Grecia lidera nueva fase de programas Interreg para impulsar cooperación y desarrollo regional
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Grecia trabaja con países vecinos a través de los programas Interreg, que son proyectos apoyados por la Unión Europea para ayudar a las regiones a cooperar y desarrollarse juntas. Estos programas buscan mejorar las economías locales, proteger el medio ambiente y fortalecer los lazos entre países.

**Qué pasó** – Ha comenzado la planificación para el próximo periodo de Interreg de 2028 a 2034, con una propuesta de presupuesto de 10 mil millones de euros por parte de la Comisión Europea. Grecia actualmente gestiona cinco programas Interreg con Bulgaria, Italia, Macedonia del Norte, Chipre y Albania, y participa en ocho más. Hasta ahora, se han realizado más de 2,500 acciones que benefician a comunidades locales y países vecinos. Grecia también ha ganado premios importantes por sus proyectos, incluyendo protección ambiental y mejoras en infraestructura.

**Impacto** – Los programas Interreg ayudan a construir confianza y paz entre países apoyando proyectos que mejoran la vida diaria, como cruces fronterizos, turismo y cuidado ambiental. Grecia juega un papel clave como punto de conexión entre la Unión Europea, los Balcanes y el Mediterráneo. Estos programas también apoyan metas importantes como energía verde, tecnología digital y unidad social. Por ejemplo, el proyecto del cruce fronterizo de Prespa mejorará la cooperación entre Grecia y Macedonia del Norte.

**Próximo paso** – El nuevo periodo de programas continuará con proyectos exitosos y lanzará otros nuevos para enfrentar desafíos actuales como el cambio climático y la recuperación económica. Grecia busca asumir un rol aún más fuerte de liderazgo en estos esfuerzos. Gobiernos locales y organizaciones seguirán trabajando juntos para aprovechar al máximo los fondos y oportunidades disponibles.

**Frase clave** – Grecia se prepara para liderar la próxima fase de los programas Interreg apoyados por la UE, fortaleciendo la cooperación regional y mejorando las comunidades transfronterizas.
